intro: Hesperis kunawarensis var. hirtula, commonly known as the Hirtula horned poppy, is a rare and distinctive flowering plant native to specific regions of Japan. It is characterized by its striking, papery petals that range in color from white to pink, often with a subtle purple tinge. The plant typically grows in rocky or mountainous habitats, preferring well-drained soils and full sunlight. Its unique morphology, including the prominent, horn-like structures on its petals, sets it apart from other members of the Papaveraceae family. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
